Introduction to Ultimate Deconvolution

Peter Carbonetto

2020-12-23

Source: vignettes/udr_intro.Rmd
udr_intro.Rmd

Here we illustrate the features of the Ultimate Deconvolution (UD) package.

library(udr)

We simulate 4,000 data points from a UD model with 4 mixture components: \[ x_i \sim w_1 N(0,V + U_1) + \cdots + w_4 N(0,V + U_4). \]

set.seed(1)
n <- 4000
V <- rbind(c(0.8,0.2),
           c(0.2,1.5))
U <- list(none   = rbind(c(0,0),
                         c(0,0)),
          shared = rbind(c(1.0,0.9),
                         c(0.9,1.0)),
          only1  = rbind(c(1,0),
                         c(0,0)),
          only2  = rbind(c(0,0),
                         c(0,1)))
w <- c(0.8,0.1,0.075,0.025)
X <- simulate_ud_data(n,w,U,V)

This is the most basic usage:

fit0 <- ud_init(X)
fit1 <- ud_fit(fit0)
# Performing Ultimate Deconvolution on 4000 x 2 matrix (udr 0.3-29, "Rcpp"):
# data points are i.i.d. (same V)
# prior covariances: 2 scaled, 4 rank-1, 4 unconstrained
# prior covariance updates: none (scaled), none (rank-1), ed (unconstrained)
# mixture weights update: em
# residual covariance update: em
# max 20 updates, conv tol 1.0e-06
# iter          log-likelihood |w - w'| |U - U'| |V - V'|
#    1 -1.2427686311528083e+04 4.09e-02 3.30e+00 2.63e-01
#    2 -1.2304140122123885e+04 1.56e-02 6.93e-01 1.23e-01
#    3 -1.2258787778612572e+04 1.12e-02 3.24e-01 6.34e-02
#    4 -1.2238592114352827e+04 8.25e-03 1.96e-01 3.61e-02
#    5 -1.2228634107038721e+04 5.99e-03 1.36e-01 2.18e-02
#    6 -1.2223365009974717e+04 4.28e-03 1.03e-01 1.37e-02
#    7 -1.2220373469123095e+04 2.99e-03 8.10e-02 8.66e-03
#    8 -1.2218531401439679e+04 2.04e-03 6.59e-02 7.05e-03
#    9 -1.2217291566752165e+04 1.66e-03 5.48e-02 6.21e-03
#   10 -1.2216382082357368e+04 1.46e-03 4.64e-02 5.52e-03
#   11 -1.2215664664949669e+04 1.31e-03 3.99e-02 4.94e-03
#   12 -1.2215066880822524e+04 1.20e-03 3.47e-02 4.47e-03
#   13 -1.2214549269280509e+04 1.12e-03 3.06e-02 4.08e-03
#   14 -1.2214089216000202e+04 1.06e-03 2.73e-02 3.75e-03
#   15 -1.2213672954458118e+04 1.01e-03 2.45e-02 3.47e-03
#   16 -1.2213291541480336e+04 9.76e-04 2.22e-02 3.23e-03
#   17 -1.2212938791490886e+04 9.47e-04 2.02e-02 3.03e-03
#   18 -1.2212610186332380e+04 9.22e-04 1.85e-02 2.85e-03
#   19 -1.2212302278259031e+04 9.00e-04 1.71e-02 2.69e-03
#   20 -1.2212012347524636e+04 8.81e-04 1.58e-02 2.55e-03

The default model is a mixture with a total of \(K = 10\) mixture components with 2 scaled, 4 rank-1, and 4 unconstrained prior covariance matrices \(U_k\):

summary(fit1)
# Model overview:
#   Number of data points: 4000
#   Dimension of data points: 2
# Data points are i.i.d. (same V)
#   Number of scaled prior covariances: 2
#   Number of rank-1 prior covariances: 4
#   Number of unconstrained prior covariances: 4
# Evaluation of fit (20 updates performed):
#   Log-likelihood: -1.221201234752e+04

The function ud_init is a flexible interface for design a variety of UD models. For example,

fit0 <- ud_init(X,U_scaled = U,n_rank1 = 1,n_unconstrained = 1,V = V)
fit2 <- ud_fit(fit0)
# Performing Ultimate Deconvolution on 4000 x 2 matrix (udr 0.3-29, "Rcpp"):
# data points are i.i.d. (same V)
# prior covariances: 4 scaled, 1 rank-1, 1 unconstrained
# prior covariance updates: none (scaled), none (rank-1), ed (unconstrained)
# mixture weights update: em
# residual covariance update: em
# max 20 updates, conv tol 1.0e-06
# iter          log-likelihood |w - w'| |U - U'| |V - V'|
#    1 -1.2363711051186072e+04 7.30e-02 5.73e+00 2.57e-01
#    2 -1.2292274931142549e+04 2.05e-02 7.56e-01 1.03e-01
#    3 -1.2267494111926884e+04 1.64e-02 3.05e-01 4.38e-02
#    4 -1.2256023670976268e+04 1.30e-02 1.72e-01 1.77e-02
#    5 -1.2249093233304877e+04 1.06e-02 1.14e-01 6.70e-03
#    6 -1.2243997672931913e+04 8.94e-03 8.32e-02 3.43e-03
#    7 -1.2239833645896120e+04 7.75e-03 6.47e-02 3.78e-03
#    8 -1.2236269664286576e+04 6.84e-03 5.26e-02 5.02e-03
#    9 -1.2233162270327024e+04 6.11e-03 4.41e-02 5.42e-03
#   10 -1.2230432724775706e+04 5.49e-03 3.78e-02 5.40e-03
#   11 -1.2228026901640827e+04 4.94e-03 3.29e-02 5.17e-03
#   12 -1.2225902045468960e+04 4.46e-03 2.91e-02 4.85e-03
#   13 -1.2224022190861437e+04 4.03e-03 2.59e-02 4.50e-03
#   14 -1.2222356363655990e+04 3.65e-03 2.32e-02 4.16e-03
#   15 -1.2220877682381668e+04 3.30e-03 2.10e-02 3.84e-03
#   16 -1.2219562768089942e+04 2.99e-03 1.91e-02 3.54e-03
#   17 -1.2218391279794114e+04 2.71e-03 1.77e-02 3.26e-03
#   18 -1.2217345519259270e+04 2.45e-03 1.65e-02 3.01e-03
#   19 -1.2216410086581143e+04 2.23e-03 1.55e-02 2.78e-03
#   20 -1.2215571578679148e+04 2.02e-03 1.46e-02 2.58e-03

The ud_fit interface also allows for flexibly re-fitting a model; that is, a ud_fit output can be used in another call to ud_fit.

Notice that the data do not need to be passed to ud_fit because they are already embedded in the ud_fit output. However, one can pass a new data set X to ud_fit.

The control argument to ud_fit controls the optimization of the model parameters. For example, the unconstrained prior covariance matrices are by default optimized using the Extreme Deconvolution (ED) updates, and we can replace these with the new “truncated eigenvalue” EM (TEEM) updates:

fit3 <- ud_fit(fit0,control = list(unconstrained.update = "teem"))
# Performing Ultimate Deconvolution on 4000 x 2 matrix (udr 0.3-29, "Rcpp"):
# data points are i.i.d. (same V)
# prior covariances: 4 scaled, 1 rank-1, 1 unconstrained
# prior covariance updates: none (scaled), none (rank-1), teem (unconstrained)
# mixture weights update: em
# residual covariance update: em
# max 20 updates, conv tol 1.0e-06
# iter          log-likelihood |w - w'| |U - U'| |V - V'|
#    1 -1.2319222292060802e+04 7.30e-02 6.88e+00 2.57e-01
#    2 -1.2271191737197005e+04 2.11e-02 4.74e-01 8.64e-02
#    3 -1.2255432620034080e+04 1.61e-02 1.83e-01 3.16e-02
#    4 -1.2247612809991640e+04 1.27e-02 9.11e-02 1.10e-02
#    5 -1.2242257433012641e+04 1.06e-02 5.28e-02 4.74e-03
#    6 -1.2237960148178690e+04 9.06e-03 3.44e-02 3.38e-03
#    7 -1.2234307726375413e+04 7.93e-03 2.47e-02 3.46e-03
#    8 -1.2231142506906435e+04 7.03e-03 1.92e-02 3.46e-03
#    9 -1.2228379012090587e+04 6.26e-03 1.59e-02 3.47e-03
#   10 -1.2225957013026069e+04 5.60e-03 1.36e-02 3.34e-03
#   11 -1.2223828605844137e+04 5.02e-03 1.20e-02 3.16e-03
#   12 -1.2221953932565955e+04 4.50e-03 1.07e-02 2.98e-03
#   13 -1.2220299250030850e+04 4.05e-03 9.62e-03 2.79e-03
#   14 -1.2218835757058101e+04 3.64e-03 8.71e-03 2.62e-03
#   15 -1.2217538749593115e+04 3.28e-03 7.91e-03 2.45e-03
#   16 -1.2216386964678833e+04 2.96e-03 7.20e-03 2.30e-03
#   17 -1.2215362053284140e+04 2.67e-03 6.57e-03 2.16e-03
#   18 -1.2214448148286296e+04 2.41e-03 5.99e-03 2.02e-03
#   19 -1.2213631505568623e+04 2.18e-03 5.48e-03 1.90e-03
#   20 -1.2212900202791410e+04 1.98e-03 5.01e-03 1.78e-03

Notice that the likelihood is slightly higher with the TEEM updates, reflecting the fact that the TEEM updates have greater freedom to optimize the covariance matrices.

These are the current model fitting defaults:

unlist(ud_fit_control_default())
#       weights.update        scaled.update         rank1.update 
#                 "em"               "none"               "none" 
# unconstrained.update         resid.update              version 
#                 "ed"                 "em"               "Rcpp" 
#              maxiter               minval                  tol 
#                 "20"             "-1e-08"              "1e-06"

The most intensive computations are implemented in R (version = R) and C++ (version = Rcpp); both versions should return the same, or nearly the same output, but the C++ version can be much faster.

The default updates for the scaled and rank-1 prior covariance matrices are "none"; they have not yet been implemented.

In some cases each sample might have different measurement error, and udr can handle such cases by specifying V as a list instead of a matrix:

fit0 <- ud_init(X,V = rep(list(V),n))

However, the ED update has not yet been implemented for this case. (The TEEM update is not applicable to this case).

fit5 <- ud_fit(fit0,control = list(unconstrained.update = "none"))
# Performing Ultimate Deconvolution on 4000 x 2 matrix (udr 0.3-29, "Rcpp"):
# data points are not i.i.d. (different Vs)
# prior covariances: 2 scaled, 4 rank-1, 4 unconstrained
# prior covariance updates: none (scaled), none (rank-1), none (unconstrained)
# mixture weights update: em
# max 20 updates, conv tol 1.0e-06
# iter          log-likelihood |w - w'| |U - U'| |V - V'|
#    1 -1.2662335972334322e+04 3.24e-02 0.00e+00 0.00e+00
#    2 -1.2573986634544281e+04 2.49e-02 0.00e+00 0.00e+00
#    3 -1.2505616818129827e+04 2.46e-02 0.00e+00 0.00e+00
#    4 -1.2452941724963250e+04 2.39e-02 0.00e+00 0.00e+00
#    5 -1.2412225731454400e+04 2.29e-02 0.00e+00 0.00e+00
#    6 -1.2380485603464937e+04 2.20e-02 0.00e+00 0.00e+00
#    7 -1.2355451032689052e+04 2.10e-02 0.00e+00 0.00e+00
#    8 -1.2335437842587164e+04 2.01e-02 0.00e+00 0.00e+00
#    9 -1.2319211144932151e+04 1.92e-02 0.00e+00 0.00e+00
#   10 -1.2305868086869421e+04 1.84e-02 0.00e+00 0.00e+00
#   11 -1.2294746778947443e+04 1.77e-02 0.00e+00 0.00e+00
